title: Who won Bake Off 2019? David Atherton announced as winner despite never being Star Baker
text:

Self-confessed “underdog” David Atherton has won The Great British Bake Off – despite not being named as Star Baker once during the series.

He beat bookies' favourite Steph Blackwell, a shop assistant who'd won the title four times during the nine-week run and geography teacher Alice Fevronia, who'd clinched it twice.

International health advisor Atherton, 36, achieved victory by impressing the judges with his picnic-themed showstopper, claiming that that he'd “saved the best til last”.

And there were no hard feelings from runner-up Alice, 28, who insisted he fully deserved his surprise win. “David just blew us out of the water - the best baker won,” she said.

(Image: Channel 4)

(Image: Channel 4)

Fellow finalist Steph, also 28, agreed: “I have made some amazing life-long friends.”

The trio were tasked with making the ultimate chocolate cake for the signature challenge and then twice baked stilton souffle for the technical. But the decision over who took the title came down to the showstopper, in which they had to create an illusion picnic basket using only cake, sweet bread and biscuits.

After lifting the trophy, David admitted it was a huge shock. “Honestly it was never in my mind that I thought I could win this.

(Image: Channel 4)

(Image: Channel 4)

“It feels so good! It’s been weeks and weeks of intensity and fatigue and then to finish it with this - I saved the best til last, and it’s the best feeling in the world. Week on week other people were stronger, I was always the underdog and yet I just managed to get through.

“All of it is a bit surreal, and I am still trying to process it, but the whole Bake Off journey is non-stop and part of it is just having the stamina.”

Judge Paul Hollywood said Yorkshire-born David fully deserved his triumph. “He has gone from nothing to win the whole thing; it’s priceless, absolutely priceless, he should be really proud of himself. I think he has done an amazing job.”

(Image: Channel 4)

And Prue Leith agreed: “David is an extraordinary baker. Right from the beginning he has never lost his temper he has always been very neat and organised. It was really a question of the tortoise catching the hare, he just steadily went on and won.”

David, who thanked his boyfriend Nik for supporting him throughout the series, said his best moment was when he'd got a coveted Hollywood Handshake during 1920s week.

But he admitted to never thinking he'd triumph because he'd had plenty of problems along the way. “The judges always loved my presentation but not my flavours so to get a first in the technical of the final was amazing.”

(Image: Channel 4)

He gave credit to his fellow finalists, gushing: “Steph and Alice bake as good as they look, they are both beautiful inside and out. The three of us were so happy to be in the final together, we were so close and really supported each other. It’s a shame we can’t all win.”

David said his secret weapon was not letting the stress get to him. “I wanted to enjoy myself rather than having any negative feelings. I am a calm person and I thought Bake Off would break me, but as it’s such a friendly environment I thrived from week to week.”

Since his win, recorded in the summer, David has kept his trophy hidden under the bed but now plans to put a potted palm on it. He intends to reward the members of his pottery class with plenty of bakes as it was they who first encouraged him to apply for the show. “I know they will be very pleased when they find out I have won,” he laughed. “They had more faith in me than I did.”

David, who was taught to bake by his mum, said he had no plans to quit his job but hinted he'd like to write a cook book. “I want to continue my role as a health adviser working with various charities all over the world, it’s a big and important part of my life.

“I love researching recipes and writing them up, so just watch this space.”
